Lena says:

Estimated.Cost:
As of March 2019, the pickleball courts are never locked,
                                            and have not been locked for months.
                                            Hopefully they will stay open and free for everyone to use.
                                            On school days, you can use the courts after school,
                                            unless there are after-school events.
                                            On weekends and other non-school days, the courts are free to use anytime.
Parking:
Use the school's upper parking lot.  What looks like a lower parking lot
                                            is actually a receiving area and needs to be kept vacant at all times.

Comments:
Donald says "a group of us play there Sundays at 1:30 all year."
                                            
                                            Patrick says "Nice weather brings out 'advanced' play on Saturdays with upwards of 20-30 players.
                                            Sunday is geared mostly towards 'beginner' or 'recreational' players.
                                            Parking on-site is free with additional street parking as needed.
                                            These courts have become the go to outdoor courts in the north end."

Several groups of players organize games at Yost Park.
                                            Some games are organized through private email lists
                                            while others are organized through the
                                            Edmonds Pickleball Facebook group.
Time:
8 a.m. to dusk.
                                            Please don't start before 8 a.m. so as to no disturb the neighbors.

1 tennis court with lines for 1 pickleball court
Pickleball.Nets: The tennis net serves as the pickleball net

Map: 1715 SE Maple Valley Hwy, Renton, WA 98057-3900

Comments:
Jeff says: "It is a pleasant rec room with hardwood floor but the compliments stop there.
                                            They have only one portable net set up and no permanent lines.
                                            Tonight they had this thin string taped to the floor at the corners.
                                            So even if you could see the lines,
                                            during play the lines would be disrupted with playing one game.
                                            The ceiling was also too low to lob.
                                            This would be a very nice place for a senior player who was just learning to play;
                                            otherwise I would not recommend anyone going there.
                                            The program here had to have been set up by someone who heard pickleball was a great game for seniors
                                            but never actually played.

Parking: Off-street parking entrance on Talbot Road S

Comments: Players sometimes tape two additional pickleball courts.

Caution:
This public "court" is defined by lines etched in the concrete of a public plaza.
                                            There is no fence or barrier around the court, which means that passersby might wander on the court
                                            and your ball might end up under someone's table, in someone's lunch or on the street.
                                            
                                            While pickleball courts measure only 22 feet wide by 44 feet long, they are supposed to be built on
                                            
                                                a minimum playing surface area measuring 30 feet wide
                                                and 60 feet long and a larger size of 40 feet by 64 feet is preferred
                                            .
                                            Unfortunately, the designers of the Hing Hay Park court don't seem to have been aware
                                            of the need to provide a playing area larger than the court itself.
                                            Click on
                                            the camera symbol above to see a picture of the court.
                                            
                                            Two tall poles can be used to attach a badminton or pickleball net. No net was available when we visited,
                                            but you might be able to get one by contacting
                                            Lisa Nielsen,
                                            Senior Recreation Program Director,
                                            Seattle Parks and Recreation.
                                            Email: Lisa.Nielsen@seattle.gov. Phone: (206) 684-7710.

Parking: Off-street parking next to the community center

Caution:
Public outdoor tennis court, also lined as one pickleball court.
                                            The pickleball baselines had not been painted the last time we checked.

Pickleball.Nets:
Permanent nets are provided.
                                            The net poles are taller than usual to allow the nets to be raised for badminton or lowered for pickleball.
                                            As of spring 2022, the mechanism to raise the nets was broken and the nets stuck in the pickleball position.
Parking: On street parking. Pay close attention to the parking signs!
Comments: As of summer 2022, pickleball players had taped a third court on the adjacent basketball court.

Parking: Off street parking at the Laurelhurst Community Center

These are very old tennis courts that probably date back to when
                                            this park was a military base. The court surface has numerous cracks
                                            and has not been maintained in ages. These courts don't seem to be
                                            part of the
                                            Seattle Parks and Recreation department official list of tennis courts.
                                            
                                            As of mid-June 2018, pickleball players are marking some of those
                                            tennis courts for pickleball play.

Use the
                                            North Seattle Pickleball Players Facebook group
                                            to find other players at this location.

Public outdoor unfenced pickleball courts.

                                            A pedestrian path passes right behind the West baselines.
                                            Beware of collision potential with toddlers, trikes, etc...
